questions.text: A 9-year-old child infected with Toxocara canis is diagnosed to have visceral larva migrans. It is an example of________.
questions.solution:
Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting a human is an example of an aberrant parasite. It is defined as a parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further.

Parasites can be classified as:

  • Ectoparasites - inhabit only the body surface of the host without penetrating the tissue. The term infestation is often used for parasitization. e.g., lice, ticks, and mites.
  • Endoparasite - lives within the body of the host and causes infection.

Endoparasites are further classified as follows:

  • Obligate parasites - cannot exist without a host. e.g., Toxoplasma gondii and Plasmodium.
  • Facultative parasites - exist as either parasitic or free-living forms. e.g., Naegleria fowleri.
  • Accidental parasites - infects an unusual host. e.g., Echinococcus granulosus infects man
  • Aberrant/Wandering parasites - infects a host where they cannot develop further. e.g., Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting humans.

questions.text: Which of the following refers to a host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development?
questions.solution:
A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is referred to as the paratenic host.

For example, in the lifecycle of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), humans are the definitive host. The first intermediate host is cyclops and the second is small freshwater fish. If the small freshwater fish with the plerocercoid larva get eaten by a larger fish, the larva survives in the larger fish. This makes the larger fish a paratenic host.

Host is an organism that harbors the parasite and provides nourishment and shelter to it. It is relatively larger than the parasite.

Types of hosts:

  • Definitive host - harbors stages of sexual reproduction of the parasite.
  • Intermediate host - harbors stages of asexual multiplication of the parasite.
  • Paratenic host - harbors only the larval stage of the parasite which remains viable without further development.
  • Reservoir host - harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other susceptible hosts, especially in endemic areas.
  • Accidental host - harbors a parasite that is not usually found in the host.

questions.text: A 46-year-old farmer came to the clinic with cough and chest pain for one week and fatigue for a month. He was diagnosed to have a hydatid cyst in his right lung. Which of the following classes does the causative organism of this disease belong to?
questions.solution:
The causative organism of hydatid disease is Echinococcus granulosus and it belongs to the class cestodes.

It is a tape-like, segmented worm. It infects man accidentally, giving rise to hydatid cysts.

The image below shows the classification of parasites.

Note: Zoonoses refers to diseases caused by zoonotic organisms. It is not a class of organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest cestode infecting humans?
questions.solution:
The smallest cestode infecting humans is Hymenolepis nana.

Option A: Diphyllobothrium latum is the longest cestode infecting man.

Option C: Heterophyes heterophyes is the smallest trematode infecting man.

Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode infecting man.

Also, Fasciolopsis buski is the largest trematode infecting humans.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites has a direct life cycle?
questions.solution:
Enterobius vermicularis has a direct life cycle.

Parasite requiring a single host to complete its development is said to have a direct life cycle.

Parasites having a direct life cycle are:

Protozoa Helminths
  • Entamoeba histolytica
  • Giardia lamblia 
  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Balantidium coli 
  • Cryptosporidium parvum 
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis 
  • Isospora belli
  • Microsporidia.
  • Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Enterobius vermicularis 
  • Trichuris trichura 
  • Ancylostoma duodenale 
  • Necator americanus 
  • Hymenolepsis nana.
 

Parasite requiring two or more hosts to complete its development is said to have indirect life cycle, e.g. Plasmodium spp.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Patient Intermediate host

1. A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly

A. Pig

2. A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema

 B. Sandfly

3. A man with a new-onset seizure and a cyst with a dot sign in MRI brain

 C. Human

4. A woman with fever and Maltese cross appearance in peripheral smear

 D. Culex mosquito
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B.

A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly is likely suffering from Kala-azar caused by Leishmania donovani. Its intermediate host is sandfly.

 

A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema is likely suffering from lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. Its intermediate host is the culex mosquito.

 

A man presenting with new-onset seizures and MRI brain showing cyst with a dot sign is likely suffering from neurocysticercosis caused by ingestion of Taenia solium eggs (Cysticercus cellulose). The intermediate host of Taenia Solium is the pig.

 

A woman having fever with her peripheral smear showing Maltese cross appearance is likely suffering from babesiosis caused by Babesia microti. Its intermediate host is human.

questions.text: An entomologist who had recently visited Mexico presented to the OPD with fever, fatigue, and an alleged history of contact with the insect given in the image. Which of the following diseases is it a biological vector for?
questions.solution:
The image shows reduviid bug which is the biological vector for the transmission of Chagas disease. Acute Chagas disease can present as fever with fatigue and a subcutaneous swelling known as a chagoma. It may lead to fatal myocarditis.

Biological vectors not only help in the transfer of parasites but the parasites undergo development or multiplication in their body as well. They are also called true vectors.

Examples of biological vectors are:

  • Mosquito - Malaria, filariasis
  • Sandfly - Kala-azar
  • Tsetse fly - Sleeping sickness
  • Reduviid bugs - Chagas disease
  • Ticks - Babesiosis

questions.text: Autoinfection is not seen with which of the following parasites?
questions.solution:
Autoinfection is not seen in infection with Ascaris lumbricoides.

Autoinfection refers to either of the following:

  • Reinfection by microbes or parasitic organisms that are present on or within the body. It is also known as internal reinfection. e.g., Strongyloides.
  • Self-infection by direct contact with a contagious agent, as with parasite eggs in the infectious state transmitted by fingernails. e.g., Pinworm.

The following are the parasites causing autoinfection (mnemonic: CHEST.C)

  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Strongyloides stercoralis
  • Taenia solium
  • Capillaria philippinensis.

questions.text: A microbiologist is doing research about antigenic variations in parasites.  Which of the following parasites will exhibit this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Trypanosoma brucei exhibits antigenic variation within the host. This genetic switch protects them from antibodies.

These trypanosomes exhibit unique antigenic variations of their glycoproteins. There is a cyclical fluctuation in the trypanosomes occurring in the blood of infected vertebrates after every 7–10 days.

Parasites exhibiting antigenic variation include:

  • Trypanosoma brucei gambiense
  • Trypanosome brucei rhodesiense
  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Giardia lamblia

 The following image shows Trypanosoma brucei.

The following image shows Plasmodium spp.

The following image shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

questions.text: You order a peripheral blood film examination while evaluating a patient with pyrexia of unknown origin. Which of the following organisms cannot be detected by this investigation?
questions.solution:
Stool examination is useful for the detection of Giardia lamblia, not peripheral blood film examination.

Examination of blood is of vital importance for demonstrating parasites that circulate in blood vessels.

Examples of parasites found in the peripheral blood film:

Protozoa Nematodes
  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Babesia spp.
  • Trypanosoma spp.
  • Leishmania spp.
  • Wuchereria bancrofti 
  • Brugia malayi 
  • Loa loa 
  • Mansonella spp.

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii cannot be done using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear.

It is done mainly by serology, which shows a rise in the titer of specific antibodies to C. burnetii.

Microorganisms such as Histoplasma, Leishmania, Toxoplasma, and Pneumocystis can also be detected with Giemsa, and in gastric tissues, Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) appear thin and distinctly blue. Giemsa’s stain is frequently used for diagnostic purposes in haematology to differentiate the nuclear and cytoplasmic morphology of platelets, RBCs, WBCs, and parasites.

questions.text: A patient has presented to the PHC with fever and chills. You order a rapid diagnostic test to detect HRP-2 antigen. Which of the following diseases is it used to diagnose?
questions.solution:
HRP-2 antigen detection is used in the diagnosis of malaria.

Malaria antigens detected by the rapid immunochromatographic test are:

  • pLDH - positivity is seen in all Plasmodium species
  • HRP-2 - positivity is specific for P. falciparum

The below image shows rapid diagnostic test (RDT) kit for malaria.

Related Pearl: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

  • Tests for antigen detection
  • Tests for antibody detection

Antigen Detection:

Antigen

Parasite

Galactose lectin antigen

Entamoeba histolytica

Giardia-specific antigen 65

Giardia lamblia

WKK and rk39 antigen

Leishmania donovani

HRP-2 antigen

Plasmodium falciparum

Vivax-specific pLDH

Plasmodium vivax

200 KD Ag and OG4C3 antigen

Wuchereria bancrofti

 

Antibody detection:

  • Complement fixation test (CFT)
  • Indirect hemagglutination test (IHA)
  • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFA)
  • Rapid immunochromatography test
  • ELISA test

questions.text: In a patient with a positive Casoni's skin test,  which of the following infections will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s skin test is done in patients with hydatid disease.

It is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction (type I).

This test is abandoned now due to non-specificity and has been supplemented by serological tests.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

The table below shows some of the important skin tests used in the diagnosis of parasitic infections.

Skin test

Diagnosis

Casoni’s test

Hydatid disease

Montenegro test/Leishmanin test

Kala-azar

Frenkel’s test

Toxoplasmosis

Fairley’s test

Schistosomiasis

Bachman test

Trichinellosis

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with cough, chest pain, and expectoration of rusty colored sputum. He is diagnosed to have an oriental lung fluke infection. Which of the following parasites is implicated here?
questions.solution:
Paragonimus westermani is commonly known as oriental lung fluke or Japanese lung fluke. It causes a pulmonary syndrome characterised by cough, chest pain and hemoptysis.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Treatment: Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

The following image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani, the oriental lung fluke.

questions.text: A college student from Mangalore comes to the OPD with intermittent fever, headache, and chills for 1 week. She gives a history of malaria 1 year back for which she had received treatment. Which of the following species you would expect to see in the peripheral smear of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malaria relapse and it is caused by Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale species.

In case of P.vivax and P.ovale, two kinds of sporozoites are seen. Some multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts while others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites (resting forms). These dormant forms may get activated and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing true clinical relapse. It usually occurs after 6 to 12 months of complete cure from the disease.

In case of P.falciparum and P.malariae, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen.

In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.

 

Malaria is endemic in Mangalore. About 80% of malaria infections in Mangalore and its surrounding areas are caused by Plasmodium vivax and the remainder is due to Plasmodium falciparum.

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Feature P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malaria
Discovered by Grassi & Feletti Stephens Welch Laveran
Erythrocyte preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes All stages Old erythrocytes
Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner’s dots (Jame’s dots) Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax
Color of pigment Yellowish-brown Yellowish-brown Black Dark brown
Hypnozoites Present Present Absent Absent
Relapse Yes Yes No No
Average IP(days) 14 14 12 (shortest) 30 (longest)
Duration of erythrocyte cycle(hours) 48 (Benign tertian) 48 (ovale tertian) 48 (malignant tertian) 72(Quartan malaria)
Others       Nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to the clinic with abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss. Stool examination revealed bile-stained eggs. Which of the following organisms may not be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Enterobius vermicularis eggs are non-bile stained and the others are bile stained.

Enterobiasis commonly occurs in young children and is characterised by anal pruritus. The worm may migrate up to the uterus, fallopian tubes and into the peritoneum in adult women. This can lead to:

  • Chronic salpingitis
  • Cervicitis
  • Peritonitis
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections.

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

questions.text: You are examining a wet mount stool sample of a patient with diarrhea. As the eggs are not visible, you concentrate the sample using the saturated salt solution technique. Which of the following eggs will not float in this technique?
questions.solution:
The eggs of Strongyloides stercoralis will not float in a saturated salt solution.

Concentration methods are used when the parasites in stool are scanty and difficult to identify in routine stool examination. It is of 2 types:

  • Floatation methods- the feces are suspended in a solution of high specific gravity and eggs will float up. e.g. saturated salt solution technique, zinc sulfate centrifugal floatation technique.
  • Sedimentation Methods - the feces are suspended in a solution with low specific gravity and eggs will sediment at the bottom. e.g. formol-ether sedimentation technique.

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.
